summary: Filters intervals based on annotations and/or count statistics

arguments.summary: Input file containing annotations for genomic intervals (output of AnnotateIntervals).  Must be provided if no counts files are provided.
arguments.name: --annotated-intervals

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: Maximum-percentile parameter for the extreme-count filter.  Intervals with a count that has a percentile strictly greater than this in a percentage of samples strictly greater than extreme-count-filter-percentage-of-samples will be filtered out.  (This is the second count-based filter applied.)
arguments.name: --extreme-count-filter-maximum-percentile

arguments.summary: Minimum-percentile parameter for the extreme-count filter.  Intervals with a count that has a percentile strictly less than this in a percentage of samples strictly greater than extreme-count-filter-percentage-of-samples will be filtered out.  (This is the second count-based filter applied.)
arguments.name: --extreme-count-filter-minimum-percentile

arguments.summary: Percentage-of-samples parameter for the extreme-count filter.  Intervals with a count that has a percentile outside of [extreme-count-filter-minimum-percentile, extreme-count-filter-maximum-percentile] in a percentage of samples strictly greater than this will be filtered out.  (This is the second count-based filter applied.)
arguments.name: --extreme-count-filter-percentage-of-samples

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: Input TSV or HDF5 files containing integer read counts in genomic intervals (output of CollectReadCounts).  Must be provided if no annotated-intervals file is provided.
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: Count-threshold parameter for the low-count filter.  Intervals with a count strictly less than this threshold in a percentage of samples strictly greater than low-count-filter-percentage-of-samples will be filtered out.  (This is the first count-based filter applied.)
arguments.name: --low-count-filter-count-threshold

arguments.summary: Percentage-of-samples parameter for the low-count filter.  Intervals with a count strictly less than low-count-filter-count-threshold in a percentage of samples strictly greater than this will be filtered out.  (This is the first count-based filter applied.)
arguments.name: --low-count-filter-percentage-of-samples

arguments.summary: Maximum allowed value for GC-content annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --maximum-gc-content

arguments.summary: Maximum allowed value for mappability annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --maximum-mappability

arguments.summary: Maximum allowed value for segmental-duplication-content annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --maximum-segmental-duplication-content

arguments.summary: Minimum allowed value for GC-content annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --minimum-gc-content

arguments.summary: Minimum allowed value for mappability annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --minimum-mappability

arguments.summary: Minimum allowed value for segmental-duplication-content annotation (inclusive).
arguments.name: --minimum-segmental-duplication-content

arguments.summary: Output Picard interval-list file containing the filtered intervals.
arguments.name: --output

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
Given specified intervals, annotated intervals output by AnnotateIntervals, and/or counts output by CollectReadCounts, outputs a filtered Picard interval list. The set intersection of intervals from the specified intervals, the annotated intervals, and the first count file will be taken as the initial set of intervals on which to perform filtering. Parameters for filtering based on the annotations and counts can be adjusted. Annotation-based filters will be applied first, followed by count-based filters. In the end, any singleton intervals (i.e., those being by themselves on their corresponding contigs) found after applying other filters will be filtered out. The result may be passed via -L to other tools (e.g., DetermineGermlineContigPloidy and GermlineCNVCaller) to mask intervals from analysis.

Inputs

  • Intervals to be filtered (typically, the bins output by PreprocessIntervals). The argument interval-merging-rule must be set to IntervalMergingRule#OVERLAPPING_ONLY and all other common arguments for interval padding or merging must be set to their defaults. A blacklist of regions in which intervals should always be filtered (regardless of other annotation-based or count-based filters) may also be provided via -XL; this can be used to filter pseudoautosomal regions (PARs), for example. Partial bins created by interval exclusion may be dropped upon intersection with the intervals present in other optional inputs.
  • (Optional) Annotated-intervals file from AnnotateIntervals. Must be provided if no counts files are provided.
  • (Optional) Counts files (TSV or HDF5 output of CollectReadCounts). Must be provided if no annotated-intervals file is provided.

Outputs

  • Filtered Picard interval-list file.

Usage examples

     gatk FilterIntervals \
          -L preprocessed_intervals.interval_list \
          -XL blacklist_intervals.interval_list \
          -I sample_1.counts.hdf5 \
          -I sample_2.counts.hdf5 \
          ... \
          --annotated-intervals annotated_intervals.tsv \
          -O filtered_intervals.interval_list
 
     gatk FilterIntervals \
          -L preprocessed_intervals.interval_list \
          --annotated-intervals annotated_intervals.tsv \
          -O filtered_intervals.interval_list
 
     gatk FilterIntervals \
          -L preprocessed_intervals.interval_list \
          -I sample_1.counts.hdf5 \
          -I sample_2.counts.hdf5 \
          ... \
          -O filtered_intervals.interval_list

Caveats

Note that a minimum mappability greater than zero and/or a maximum segmental duplication content less than one both have the potential to exclude real variant calls by excluding their intervals due to these criteria.
name: FilterIntervals
